SENT.plain: BACKGROUND AIMS: Aplastic anemia (AA) is a rare but potentially life-threatening disease
There is a need for the development of new, more effective and less toxic therapies for treating AA
The safety and efficacy of an immune cell-based therapy for AA was examined
METHODS: Thirty-one patients with idiopathic AA received intravenous infusions of ex vivo-activated autologous and allogeneic immune cells at least once a week
Response to therapy was assessed by symptoms, transfusion dependency, blood counts, bone marrow biopsy and survival
RESULTS: Of the 31 patients, 25 (81%) had either complete (11, 35%) or partial (14, 45%) responses, while six (19%) showed no response to the therapy
The overall survival rates at 3 years were 90%
CONCLUSIONS: The therapy described appears to be safe and effective
The data from this pilot study suggest that a larger, controlled study is warranted
